channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Answers About the Hajj: What’s in the Kaaba and Where to Find Bathrooms
item.media:description: A woman paused during her circulations of the Kaaba at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.
item.description: Diaa Hadid, a Times correspondent making the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca, answers questions from readers.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Syria Is Calmer but Cautious as Cease-Fire Begins
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, center, in the Damascus suburb of Daraya on Monday morning, in a photograph released by the official Syrian news agency. Rebels had long held the suburb, but surrendered it last month.
item.description: The truce, which has drawn skepticism, led to a reduction of violence in its early hours, but there were some reported violations by both sides.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Israel Denies Claims That Syria Shot Down Warplane and Drone
item.media:description: Israeli tanks during a training exercise in the Israeli-held part of the Golan Heights this month.
item.description: Two missiles were fired at aircraft that were targeting artillery positions in the Syrian Golan Heights, but neither came close, the Israeli military said.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: The View From Syria as a Cease-Fire Takes Effect
item.media:description: A man and his son prayed at the grave of a relative in the rebel-held town of Douma, just east of Damascus, on Monday.
item.description: Syrians celebrated the Eid holiday, and shared in skepticism of the truce: “Here, people can’t believe anything. But they are always waiting for peace.”
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Abroad in America: Fearful and Flummoxed: Watching the Presidential Race From Abroad
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump made at a campaign stop Boulevard Diner in Dundalk, Md., on Monday.
item.description: Foreigners feel invested in the campaign’s outcome and raise questions about American law, during the election and beyond.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Brazil’s Congress Expels Lawmaker Who Led Ouster of President
item.media:description: Eduardo Cunha, the former speaker of Brazil’s lower house of Congress, during a session on Monday in Brasília at which lawmakers voted to remove him from office.
item.description: The lower house of Congress voted overwhelmingly Monday night to expel Eduardo Cunha, a conservative lawmaker who is facing graft charges.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: With U.S. Election in Sight, Ban Ki-moon Seeks Quick Action on Climate Accord
item.media:description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations.
item.description: Heeding a threat of withdrawal by Donald J. Trump, the secretary general wants at least 55 countries to commit to the pact for at least the next four years.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: U.S. and South Korea to Seek Strong Punishment Over North’s Nuclear Test
item.media:description: An American bomber, center, flying over Osan Air Base in South Korea.
item.description: They vowed to push for a resolution at the United Nations Security Council that includes new sanctions and the removal of existing loopholes.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Mother’s Killing of Children in Rural China Spurs Debate About Inequality
item.description: The case of a mother who killed herself and her four children has ignited concerns about the grim realities rural families face amid rampant inequality.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Italy’s ‘Fertility Day’ Call to Make Babies Arouses Anger, Not Ardor
item.media:description: “The government encourages us to have babies and then the main welfare system in Italy is still the grandparents,” said Vittoria Iacovella, a journalist and mother of two girls.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: A government ad campaign aimed at tackling Italy’s low birthrate was swiftly abandoned after it was widely deemed offensive.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Jutta Limbach, First Woman to Lead Germany’s Highest Court, Dies at 82
item.media:description: Jutta Limbach in 2002 at a session of the Federal Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe, Germany.
item.description: Ms. Limbach, who was 11 when World War II ended, also led a commission to mediate disputes about the restitution of art seized by the Nazis.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: South Sudan Leaders Amass Great Wealth as Nation Suffers, Report Says
item.media:description: South Sudanese refugees in the remote northwestern district of Adjumani, in Uganda, near the border with South Sudan in August.
item.description: A report by an advocacy group in Washington suggests that a desire to control of natural resources, not an ethnic feud, is at the root of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Wukan, a Chinese Village, Erupts in Unrest Over Activists’ Arrests
item.media:description: Lin Zuluan, a leader in Wukan, was sentenced recently to three years in prison on corruption charges. Residents have held daily protests to call for his release.
item.description: The police responded with rubber bullets and tear gas, bloodying several people, according to interviews with villagers and images posted online.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Germany Arrests 3 Syrians on Suspicion of ISIS Ties
item.media:description: Refugees at a station in Vienna tried to board trains for Germany last year.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: They are thought to have arrived in the country among hundreds of thousands of migrants and to have had links to those behind the Paris attacks lacks year.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sinosphere: Theater’s Evolving Role in China and Taiwan
item.media:description: A scene from a production of “A Dream Like a Dream” by Stan Lai in Beijing. The play has audiences sitting on swivel chairs in the center of the stage.
item.description: Stan Lai, a celebrated Chinese-language playwright and director, discusses changes in the theater industry and how his Buddhist beliefs influence his writing.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Visions of Life on Mars in Earth’s Depths
item.media:description: A team led by Tullis C. Onstott of Princeton University looking for life-forms that could give insights to possible life elsewhere in the solar system in the Beatrix mine in South Africa.
item.description: Far down in a South African gold mine, scientists are studying tiny life-forms that live in eternal darkness. The conditions provide insights into where life might exist elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: Benjamin Netanyahu Draws Fire After Saying Palestinians Support ‘Ethnic Cleansing’
item.description: In the latest in a series of videos, Israel’s prime minister assailed Palestinian leaders’ opposition to new West Bank settlements.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: It’s Not the Bullets Forcing Yemeni Troops Off the Battlefield. It’s the Pay.
item.media:description: Pro-government fighters outside Taiz, Yemen, last month.
item.description: Officials in Yemen are struggling to contain the growing anger of pro-government fighters over delayed payments from the Saudi Arabia-led coalition.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: David Cameron Steps Down From His Seat in British Parliament
item.description: The former British prime minister said he is leaving the House of Commons because his continued presence would be a distraction to the new government.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Violence Erupts in Southern India Over Order to Share Water
item.media:description: Riot police officers in Bangalore, India, in Karnataka State on Monday after protesters set fire to vehicles. Karnataka was ordered to release water to neighboring Tamil Nadu State.
item.description: Protesters in Bangalore threw rocks and set fire to vehicles after the Indian Supreme Court ordered Karnataka State to release river water to neighboring Tamil Nadu.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Mexico City Journal: Mexico City’s Organ Grinders, Once Beloved, Feel Shunned
item.media:description: Oscar Rosas, 20, who comes from a family of organ grinders, played for tips last month in Mexico City.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: While their numbers may be growing, organists worry that a younger generation does not share the desire to preserve their culture and fails to appreciate the craft.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: South Korea’s President Warns of More Provocations From North
item.description: President Park Geun-hye ruled out dialogue with the North, saying that its nuclear program was “not a bargaining chip” but a “present and urgent threat.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Repeat of Austria’s Presidential Runoff Faces a Delay
item.media:description: Alexander Van der Bellen, left, and Norbert Hofer, the candidates in the Austrian presidential election, at a debate in May.
item.description: The country’s interior minister said faulty postal ballots meant the vote should be postponed, another embarrassing glitch in an election originally held in May.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: What in the World: Fear Descends Over Australia as Magpie Swooping Season Begins
item.description: It’s swooping season for the native magpie in Australia, and the birds are dive bombing and pecking at anything they deem a threat, especially humans.
item.dc:creator: SERENA SOLOMON

item.title: What in the World: Turkey’s Suspicious Mind-Set Has Been a Century in the Making
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photography by Filip Fuxa/shutterstock
item.description: The Turks’ notion of a vast Western conspiracy to undermine their country, with the United States mostly to blame, has its roots in a post-World War I treaty that was never carried out.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Fixes: For Refugees in Lebanon, Cash Instead of Camps
item.media:description: Syrian women wait in line to receive assistance in Lebanon.
item.description: With debit cards rather than bagged food, refugees buy their produce, live in more dignity, and raise less resentment among their Lebanese neighbors.
item.dc:creator: TINA ROSENBERG

item.title: Editorial: Keep the Pressure on Myanmar
item.media:description: Aung San Suu Kyi, center, at a peace conference in August, in Naypyidaw, Myanmar.
item.description: It would be a mistake for the United States to lift all remaining sanctions on Myanmar now.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How the Next President Can Stop North Korea
item.description: The Obama administration’s policy has failed to halt Pyongyang’s nuclear program. But the next White House still has a chance.
item.dc:creator: JOEL S. WIT

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
